discussion.content: Technically you should disable system restore, but since the question specifies that the computer can't enter into standard desktop, it is probably best to go with safe mode.

Selected Answer: D
It should be D only.

comments.content: you couldn't disable the system restore if you were not able to boot your system, "you should know this by now" =p

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Come on, you should know this by now!

"The 1002 exam outlines the following multistep
process as the best practice procedures for malware removal:
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine the infected systems.
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows).
4. Remediate the infected systems.
A. Update the anti-malware software.
B. Scan and use removal techniques (Safe Mode, Preinstallation
Environment).
5. Schedule scans and run updates.
6. Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows).
7. Educate the end user."
Taken from Mike Meyers' book

A. Disable system restore. 
You can disable system restore without the standard desktop. In Mike Meyers video, he goes into the Windows Recovery Environment > Troubleshoot > then there is an option for command prompt. You can disable System Restore from the command prompt by disabling its registry key
Is it possible to disable system restore in Safe mode?
If windows safe mode not booting too, best bet is a windows PE bootup disk.

comments.content: That makes sense, I agree with you.

discussion.content: D is absolutely correct answer. Boot into safe mode if you cannot boot in standard mode. Try to scan for malware using malwarebytes - You cannot disable system restore without being able to boot it up so why would you choose A?
I guess, to do a system restore, you need to access your desktop and if that is not possible next best option would be to boot into safe mode and disable system restore.
so you have to be able to turn it on in order to disable system restore
The machine is quarantined but still can't boot into a Standard Destop
Surely disable system restore is the next step after quarantine????

comments.content: How when the computer cant boot into desktop? You have to access the system restore in order for you to disable it.
but still cannot boot into a standard desktop.

questions.question_text:
A technician is attempting to repair a Windows computer that is infected with malware. The machine is quarantined but still cannot boot into a standard desktop.
Which of the following is the most likely NEXT step?

discussion.content: its A and F

questions.question_text:
A company has just experienced a data breach that affected all mobile devices.
Which of the following would BEST secure access to user's mobile devices? (Choose two.)

A technician is troubleshooting a printer issue on a Windows computer and wants to disable the printer to test a theory.
Which of the following should the technician use to accomplish this?

discussion.content: C is correct. If you go to Device Manager, open "Print Ques" and right click on your printer. You will be able to click "disable device" on the printer you want to disable.

Selected Answer: C
Device manager is the way to go here
Device Manager is correct. device Manager>any driver > right-click(it shows an option of disable device)
How can you disable printer from Device manager, i think should be Device and printers.

comments.content: yeah you can also use devices and printers, but I think device manager is faster.
Where did you get python from? Have you never heard of vi?
grep vi would search for and return processes named vi. vi is a text editor in Linux.

discussion.content:
ps aux command options 
a:- This option prints the running processes from all users.
u:- This option shows user or owner column in output.
x:- This option prints the processes those have not been executed from the terminal.
Collectively the options "aux" print all the running process in system regardless from where they have been executed.
Second, we piped that output to grep –i python, which simple states “go to grep and filter out and return everything with ‘python’ in it.” The –i option is there to ignore-case, as grep is case-sensitive.
The –v option tells grep to invert its output, meaning that instead of printing matching lines, do the opposite and print all of the lines that don’t match the expression.

-i option is Bonus :)

questions.question_text:
A technician logs on to a Linux computer and runs the following command: ps -aux | grep vi
Which of the following MOST accurately describes the effect of the command?

choices.B: It opens a list of directories that start with the letters vi.
choices.D: If finds a list of processes running a text editor.
choices.C: It creates a new file named grep in the current working directory.
choices.A: It kills any running programs starting with the letters vi.

questions.question_text:
A small office calls a technician to investigate some `invalid certificate` errors from a concerned user. The technician observes that whenever the user attempts to access a secure website from the Windows desktop, this error is encountered. No other users in the office are experiencing this error.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Disable the SPI firewall on the office's gateway and any other routers.
choices.E: Create an outbound rule in Windows Firewall named after the user's homepage.
choices.F: Run anti-malware scans and download the latest Windows updates.
choices.B: Assist the user with purchasing an SSL certificate and save the certificate to the desktop.
choices.A: Remove any proxy servers configured on the user's browsers.
choices.D: Instruct the user to ignore the certificate error since the user is connecting to a secure website.

comments.content: Not going to lie, I chuckled.

In the real world 100% this would be first thought. CMOS battery is dead, system time and date are being reset on every startup. So every certificate you run into is being rejected because your computer doesn't think it's in date.
I understand why they want A and F for this though. The implication is that there is malware on the machine that has configured your browser to run every request through a malicious proxy server, a classic way to try to grab credentials. If this is the case then the user is seeing this error because they are being passed a bad certificate, most likely from the malicious proxy server in an attempt to bypass SSL so they can see any login details you use.
The time and date solution is much more likely but i guess would come under the 1001 learning objectives instead of the core 1002.
I was looking for the Date and Time option... I learned on the CompTia CertMaster that Invalid certificate usually means the date and time issues...

discussion.content: G. Check there system's date and time?

comments.content: I know right - logic of COMPTIA...

discussion.content: "When in doubt, ALWAYS patch and upgrade"
Malware could modify the list of certificates. It could also initiate session hijacking, web page-spoofing and browser redirection.
A and F are the only sensible answers. I experienced this many times with users.
I'd imagine he has malware that's why only he has a proxy server.

comments.content: There's a big difference between an external website and internal servers. Never simply ignore certificate warnings where external websites are involved.
The malware sets up a proxy server in your browser dumbass

discussion.content:
Not A - Are we to believe that this user is the only one in the office using these proxy servers? Highly unlikely. Most offices configure all workstations with the same proxy settings - nobody else is experiencing this problem.
D - More likely - in real life right now that's exactly what we do in our local office - one of our HR servers in a remote office always gives us an invalid certificate warning week after week - the remote office techs won't update their server certificate, so we simply ignore the warning and proceed to it anyway - we trust it - happens frequently.
F - Run anti-malware scan and download and install the latest updates.
